action.action-desc: Mr. Trone (for himself, Mr. Katko, Mr. Correa, and Mr. Meijer) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Agriculture

form.official-title: To amend the Food and Nutrition Act of 2008 to limit the use of business integrity and reputation factors in determining the eligibility of a retail food store or wholesale food concern to be approved to accept and redeem supplemental nutrition assistance program benefits.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the SNAP Second Chance Act of 2022.

section.header: Business integrity and reputation under supplemental nutrition assistance program
section.text: Section 9(a)(1)(B) of the Food and Nutrition Act of 2008 (7 U.S.C. 2018(a)(1)(B)) is amended—

paragraph.text: in clause (v), by inserting , in accordance with clause (ii) before the period at the end;
by redesignating clauses (i) through (v) as subclauses (I) through (V), respectively, and indenting appropriately;
in the matter preceding subclause (I) (as so redesignated), by striking In determining and inserting the following:
by adding at the end the following:

clause.header: Treatment of criminal convictions under business integrity and reputation

subclause.header: Definition of crime of financial fraud or deception
subclause.text: In this clause, the term crime of financial fraud or deception means a crime involving—

subitem.text: an application for a Federal loan or other Federal financial assistance.

subclause.text: In considering the business integrity and reputation of the applicant under clause (i)(V), a conviction of an applicant shall be taken into account only if the conviction is for—

item.text: a crime of financial fraud or deception under Federal, State, or Tribal law, that occurred during the 5-year period preceding the date of application, or
a crime under section 15 of this Act.

section.text: Not later than 18 months after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall promulgate regulations to carry out the amendments made by section 2.
